title: Avoidable deaths are on the rise in the United States, yet falling in many peer nations

title: Peacekeeper cells protect the body from autoimmunity during infection
summary: New research shows how a specially trained population of immune cells keeps the peace by preventing other immune cells from attacking their own. The study provides a better understanding of immune regulation during infection and could provide a foundation for interventions to prevent or reverse autoimmune diseases.

title: Scientists witness living plant cells generate cellulose and form cell walls
summary: In a groundbreaking study on the synthesis of cellulose -- a major constituent of all plant cell walls -- a team has captured images of the microscopic process of cell-wall building continuously over 24 hours with living plant cells, providing critical insights that may lead to the development of more robust plants for increased food and lower-cost biofuels production. The discovery reveals a dynamic process never seen before and may provide practical applications for everyday products derived from plants including enhanced textiles, biofuels, biodegradable plastics, and new medical products.

summary: A researcher has conducted an experimental demonstration of intricate and previously theorized behaviors in the fundamental patterns that govern oscillatory systems in nature and technology.

title: At-home smell test for early detection of Alzheimer's disease
summary: Researchers developed olfactory tests -- in which participants sniff odor labels that have been placed on a card -- to assess people's ability to discriminate, identify and remember odors. title: Citrus remedy squeezes out dry mouth for cancer patients
summary: A natural citrus oil from oranges, lemons, and limes is proving highly effective in relieving dry mouth, and when combined with a new lipid formulation, new research suggests it may be effective without significant side effects. title: 'Low-sugar' vaccine can provide broad immunity against coronavirus variants
summary: Early animal studies show that a single vaccine could protect the recipient from different variants of the coronaviruses that cause COVID-19, the flu and the common cold. In addition to creating antibodies that target a specific region of the spike protein that doesn't mutate, the vaccine removes the sugar coat from the virus that allows it to hide in the body.

title: Hydrophilic coating makes for unflappable golf balls

title: C. diff uses toxic compound to fuel growth advantage

summary: Pro-environmental behavior increases among school students who participate in insect-related citizen science projects, according to new research.

title: Healthy eating in midlife linked to overall healthy aging
summary: Maintaining a healthy diet rich in plant-based foods, with low to moderate intake of healthy animal-based foods and lower intake of ultra-processed foods, was linked to a higher likelihood of healthy aging -- defined as reaching age 70 free of major chronic diseases and with cognitive, physical, and mental health maintained, according to a new study. The study is among the first to examine multiple dietary patterns in midlife in relation to overall healthy aging.

title: Household electricity three times more expensive than upcoming 'eco-friendly' aviation e-fuels, study reveals
summary: Existing tax policies during the energy transition from fossil fuels to renewable sources will lead to major energy injustices and skewed priorities, new research shows.

title: Helicopter crashes during South Korea's 'worst ever fires'
summary: The wildfires are threatening cultural sites and "rewriting the record books", according to authorities.

title: Chewing gum can shed microplastics into saliva, pilot study finds
summary: Plastic is everywhere in our daily lives. And much of what we use, such as cutting boards, clothes and cleaning sponges, can expose us to tiny, micrometer-wide plastic particles called microplastics.

title: Gas injection setup in new fusion system is guided by public-private research
summary: Researchers have determined that six gas valves provide the best protection against plasma disruptions in SPARC, a next-generation, experimental fusion system. By refining the setup for the fusion vessel's massive gas injection system, researchers are ensuring that disruptions -- sudden jets of plasma that can damage the fusion vessel's inner walls -- are controlled efficiently, paving the way for safer, more robust fusion power plants.

title: What does 'that' mean in 'Did you see that?'
summary: What goes through your mind when someone asks 'Did you see that?' A study shows that children and adults process ambiguous information like 'that' differently. While children focus more on the literal meaning, adults use multiple cues to grasp the speaker's intent.

title: Making foie gras without force-feeding
summary: Researchers wondered if there was a more ethical way to enjoy foie gras, so they created a process to replicate the dish without force-feeding ducks and geese beyond their normal diets. They treated the fat with the bird's own lipases, mimicking the activities that occur naturally in the duck's body, and the resultant foie gras looked correct with noninvasive laser microscopy.

title: The best 'butter' for a vegan shortbread
summary: Researchers examine the properties of several dairy-free butter alternatives inside one of the region's most well-known snacks: Scottish shortbread. The group tested the alternatives in their lab, selecting three types of vegan butter substitutes with different levels of fat and comparing their consistencies and responses to heat.

title: Study confirms accuracy of blood test for early Alzheimer's detection in Asian populations
summary: A study has demonstrated the high accuracy of plasma p-tau217 as a blood-based biomarker for detecting abnormal brain beta-amyloid pathology, a hallmark of Alzheimer's disease.

title: A simple way to boost math progress
summary: Scientists investigated whether email interventions informed by behavioral science could help teachers help students learn math.

title: Affordable sensing system to restore sense of touch in minimally invasive surgery
summary: Researchers have developed an innovative sensing system that restores the missing tactile feedback in minimally invasive surgery (MIS), enhancing precision, ease of use, and safety. The new 'off-the-jaw' system integrates force and angle sensors into the handle of laparoscopic tools, providing surgeons with real-time measurements of grasping forces and insights into tissue stiffness and thickness.

title: New IVF method mimics fallopian tube environment, increasing sperm viability
summary: The success of in vitro fertilization depends on many factors, one of which is sperm viability. A recent study documents a new way to select viable sperm and prolong their viability in the laboratory, reducing one source of variability during the process.

title: New tool enables remote hardware troubleshooting
summary: A team of researchers has developed a new tool designed to revolutionize hardware troubleshooting, with the help of 3D phone scans.

title: Chimpanzees act as 'engineers', choosing materials to make tools based on structural and mechanical properties
summary: Researchers have discovered that chimpanzees living in Gombe Stream National Park in Tanzania employ a degree of engineering when making their tools, deliberately choosing plants that provide materials that produce more flexible tools for termite fishing.

title: The right moves to rein in fibrosis
summary: Biomedical researchers have decoded how mechanical forces drive cell behavior in fibrosis.

title: Fatty liver linked to increased risk of death from several diseases
summary: A comprehensive study shows that people with fatty liver disease have almost twice the mortality rate of the general population. They have an increased risk of dying from both liver diseases and common diseases such as cancer and cardiovascular disease.

title: New machine learning framework enhances precision and efficiency in metal 3D printing, advancing sustainable manufacturing
summary: Researchers are leveraging machine learning to improve additive manufacturing, also commonly known as 3D printing. The team introduces a new framework they've dubbed the Accurate Inverse process optimization framework in laser Directed Energy Deposition (AIDED).

title: Transition point in romantic relationships signals the beginning of their end
summary: The end of a romantic relationship usually does not come out of the blue but is indicated one or two years before the breakup. As the results of a psychological study have demonstrated, the terminal stage of a relationship consists of two phases.

title: Bubbly idea: Ultrafine bubble showers suppress atopic dermatitis
summary: A medical research team has confirmed that ultrafine bubble showers significantly suppress inflammation in mice with atopic dermatitis due to external factors.

title: 5,700-year storm archive shows rise in tropical storms and hurricanes in the Caribbean
summary: A storm, even once it has passed, can leave traces in the ocean that last for thousands of years. These consist of sediment layers composed of coarse particles, which are different from the finer sediments associated with good weather.

title: New non-surgical contraceptive implant is delivered through tiny needles
summary: Investigators have developed a long-acting contraceptive implant that can be delivered through tiny needles to minimize patient discomfort and increase the likelihood of medication use. Their findings in preclinical models provide the technological basis to develop self-administrable contraceptive shots that could mimic the long-term drug release of surgically implanted devices.

title: How extreme weather threatens nature's essential services
summary: A new model suggests that timber production in Minnesota could decrease by half as windstorms intensify with climate change.

title: Oxygen for Mars
summary: To mitigate global climate change, emissions of the primary culprit, carbon dioxide, must be drastically reduced. A newly developed process helps solve this problem: CO2 is directly split electrochemically into carbon and oxygen.

title: How chromosomes shape up for cell division
summary: For successful cell division, chromosomal DNA needs to be packed into compact rod-shaped structures. Defects in this process can lead to cell death or diseases like cancer.

title: Southeast Asia's fisheries benefit from small-scale, multispecies capture
summary: Despite decades of warnings about overfishing, Southeast Asia's capture fisheries have proven remarkably robust.
